speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: SCENE III. Brutus's tent.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Enter BRUTUS and CASSIUS

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: That you have wrong'd me doth appear in this:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: You have condemn'd and noted Lucius Pella

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: For taking bribes here of the Sardians;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Wherein my letters, praying on his side,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Because I knew the man, were slighted off.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: You wronged yourself to write in such a case.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: In such a time as this it is not meet

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: That every nice offence should bear his comment.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Let me tell you, Cassius, you yourself

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Are much condemn'd to have an itching palm;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: To sell and mart your offices for gold

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: To undeservers.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I an itching palm!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: You know that you are Brutus that speak this,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Or, by the gods, this speech were else your last.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The name of Cassius honours this corruption,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And chastisement doth therefore hide his head.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Chastisement!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Remember March, the ides of March remember:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Did not great Julius bleed for justice' sake?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: What villain touch'd his body, that did stab,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And not for justice? What, shall one of us

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That struck the foremost man of all this world

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: But for supporting robbers, shall we now

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Contaminate our fingers with base bribes,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And sell the mighty space of our large honours

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: For so much trash as may be grasped thus?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I had rather be a dog, and bay the moon,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Than such a Roman.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Brutus, bay not me;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I'll not endure it: you forget yourself,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: To hedge me in; I am a soldier, I,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Older in practise, abler than yourself

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: To make conditions.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Go to; you are not, Cassius.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I am.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I say you are not.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Urge me no more, I shall forget myself;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Have mind upon your health, tempt me no further.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Away, slight man!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Is't possible?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Hear me, for I will speak.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Must I give way and room to your rash choler?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Shall I be frighted when a madman stares?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: O ye gods, ye gods! must I endure all this?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: All this! ay, more: fret till your proud heart break;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Go show your slaves how choleric you are,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And make your bondmen tremble. Must I budge?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Must I observe you? must I stand and crouch

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Under your testy humour? By the gods

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: You shall digest the venom of your spleen,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Though it do split you; for, from this day forth,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I'll use you for my mirth, yea, for my laughter,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: When you are waspish.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Is it come to this?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: You say you are a better soldier:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Let it appear so; make your vaunting true,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And it shall please me well: for mine own part,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I shall be glad to learn of noble men.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: You wrong me every way; you wrong me, Brutus;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I said, an elder soldier, not a better:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Did I say 'better'?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: If you did, I care not.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: When Caesar lived, he durst not thus have moved me.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Peace, peace! you durst not so have tempted him.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I durst not!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: No.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: What, durst not tempt him!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: For your life you durst not!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Do not presume too much upon my love;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I may do that I shall be sorry for.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: You have done that you should be sorry for.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: There is no terror, Cassius, in your threats,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: For I am arm'd so strong in honesty

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That they pass by me as the idle wind,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Which I respect not. I did send to you

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: For certain sums of gold, which you denied me:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: For I can raise no money by vile means:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: By heaven, I had rather coin my heart,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And drop my blood for drachmas, than to wring

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: From the hard hands of peasants their vile trash

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: By any indirection: I did send

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: To you for gold to pay my legions,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Which you denied me: was that done like Cassius?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Should I have answer'd Caius Cassius so?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: When Marcus Brutus grows so covetous,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: To lock such rascal counters from his friends,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Be ready, gods, with all your thunderbolts;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Dash him to pieces!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I denied you not.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: You did.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I did not: he was but a fool that brought

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: My answer back. Brutus hath rived my heart:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: A friend should bear his friend's infirmities,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: But Brutus makes mine greater than they are.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I do not, till you practise them on me.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: You love me not.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I do not like your faults.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: A friendly eye could never see such faults.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: A flatterer's would not, though they do appear

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: As huge as high Olympus.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Come, Antony, and young Octavius, come,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Revenge yourselves alone on Cassius,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: For Cassius is aweary of the world;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Hated by one he loves; braved by his brother;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Cheque'd like a bondman; all his faults observed,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Set in a note-book, learn'd, and conn'd by rote,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: To cast into my teeth. O, I could weep

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: My spirit from mine eyes! There is my dagger,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And here my naked breast; within, a heart

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Dearer than Plutus' mine, richer than gold:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: If that thou be'st a Roman, take it forth;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I, that denied thee gold, will give my heart:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Strike, as thou didst at Caesar; for, I know,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: When thou didst hate him worst, thou lovedst him better

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Than ever thou lovedst Cassius.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Sheathe your dagger:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Be angry when you will, it shall have scope;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Do what you will, dishonour shall be humour.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: O Cassius, you are yoked with a lamb

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That carries anger as the flint bears fire;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Who, much enforced, shows a hasty spark,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And straight is cold again.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Hath Cassius lived

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: To be but mirth and laughter to his Brutus,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: When grief, and blood ill-temper'd, vexeth him?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: When I spoke that, I was ill-temper'd too.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Do you confess so much? Give me your hand.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And my heart too.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: O Brutus!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: What's the matter?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Have not you love enough to bear with me,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: When that rash humour which my mother gave me

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Makes me forgetful?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Yes, Cassius; and, from henceforth,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: When you are over-earnest with your Brutus,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: He'll think your mother chides, and leave you so.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: [Within]  Let me go in to see the generals;

speaker: Poet
text_entry: There is some grudge between 'em, 'tis not meet

speaker: Poet
text_entry: They be alone.

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: [Within]  You shall not come to them.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: [Within]  Nothing but death shall stay me.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Enter Poet, followed by LUCILIUS, TITINIUS, and LUCIUS

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: How now! what's the matter?

speaker: Poet
text_entry: For shame, you generals! what do you mean?

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Love, and be friends, as two such men should be;

speaker: Poet
text_entry: For I have seen more years, I'm sure, than ye.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Ha, ha! how vilely doth this cynic rhyme!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Get you hence, sirrah; saucy fellow, hence!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Bear with him, Brutus; 'tis his fashion.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I'll know his humour, when he knows his time:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: What should the wars do with these jigging fools?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Companion, hence!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Away, away, be gone.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Exit Poet

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Lucilius and Titinius, bid the commanders

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Prepare to lodge their companies to-night.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And come yourselves, and bring Messala with you

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Immediately to us.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Exeunt LUCILIUS and TITINIUS

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Lucius, a bowl of wine!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Exit LUCIUS

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I did not think you could have been so angry.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: O Cassius, I am sick of many griefs.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Of your philosophy you make no use,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: If you give place to accidental evils.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: No man bears sorrow better. Portia is dead.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Ha! Portia!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: She is dead.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: How 'scaped I killing when I cross'd you so?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: O insupportable and touching loss!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Upon what sickness?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Impatient of my absence,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And grief that young Octavius with Mark Antony

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Have made themselves so strong:--for with her death

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That tidings came;--with this she fell distract,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And, her attendants absent, swallow'd fire.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And died so?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Even so.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: O ye immortal gods!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Re-enter LUCIUS, with wine and taper

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Speak no more of her. Give me a bowl of wine.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: In this I bury all unkindness, Cassius.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: My heart is thirsty for that noble pledge.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Fill, Lucius, till the wine o'erswell the cup;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I cannot drink too much of Brutus' love.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Come in, Titinius!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Exit LUCIUS

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Re-enter TITINIUS, with MESSALA

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Welcome, good Messala.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Now sit we close about this taper here,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And call in question our necessities.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Portia, art thou gone?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: No more, I pray you.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Messala, I have here received letters,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That young Octavius and Mark Antony

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Come down upon us with a mighty power,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Bending their expedition toward Philippi.

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Myself have letters of the selfsame tenor.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: With what addition?

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: That by proscription and bills of outlawry,

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Octavius, Antony, and Lepidus,

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Have put to death an hundred senators.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Therein our letters do not well agree;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Mine speak of seventy senators that died

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: By their proscriptions, Cicero being one.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Cicero one!

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Cicero is dead,

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: And by that order of proscription.

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Had you your letters from your wife, my lord?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: No, Messala.

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Nor nothing in your letters writ of her?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Nothing, Messala.

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: That, methinks, is strange.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Why ask you? hear you aught of her in yours?

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: No, my lord.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Now, as you are a Roman, tell me true.

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Then like a Roman bear the truth I tell:

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: For certain she is dead, and by strange manner.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Why, farewell, Portia. We must die, Messala:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: With meditating that she must die once,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I have the patience to endure it now.

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Even so great men great losses should endure.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I have as much of this in art as you,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: But yet my nature could not bear it so.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Well, to our work alive. What do you think

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Of marching to Philippi presently?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I do not think it good.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Your reason?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: This it is:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: 'Tis better that the enemy seek us:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: So shall he waste his means, weary his soldiers,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Doing himself offence; whilst we, lying still,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Are full of rest, defense, and nimbleness.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Good reasons must, of force, give place to better.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The people 'twixt Philippi and this ground

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Do stand but in a forced affection;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: For they have grudged us contribution:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The enemy, marching along by them,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: By them shall make a fuller number up,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Come on refresh'd, new-added, and encouraged;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: From which advantage shall we cut him off,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: If at Philippi we do face him there,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: These people at our back.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Hear me, good brother.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Under your pardon. You must note beside,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That we have tried the utmost of our friends,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Our legions are brim-full, our cause is ripe:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The enemy increaseth every day;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: We, at the height, are ready to decline.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: There is a tide in the affairs of men,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Which, taken at the flood, leads on to fortune;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Omitted, all the voyage of their life

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Is bound in shallows and in miseries.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: On such a full sea are we now afloat;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And we must take the current when it serves,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Or lose our ventures.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Then, with your will, go on;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: We'll along ourselves, and meet them at Philippi.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The deep of night is crept upon our talk,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And nature must obey necessity;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Which we will niggard with a little rest.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: There is no more to say?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: No more. Good night:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Early to-morrow will we rise, and hence.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Lucius!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Enter LUCIUS

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: My gown.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Exit LUCIUS

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Farewell, good Messala:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Good night, Titinius. Noble, noble Cassius,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Good night, and good repose.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: O my dear brother!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: This was an ill beginning of the night:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Never come such division 'tween our souls!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Let it not, Brutus.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Every thing is well.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Good night, my lord.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Good night, good brother.

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Good night, Lord Brutus.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Farewell, every one.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Exeunt all but BRUTUS

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Re-enter LUCIUS, with the gown

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Give me the gown. Where is thy instrument?

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Here in the tent.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: What, thou speak'st drowsily?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Poor knave, I blame thee not; thou art o'er-watch'd.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Call Claudius and some other of my men:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I'll have them sleep on cushions in my tent.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Varro and Claudius!

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Enter VARRO and CLAUDIUS

speaker: VARRO
text_entry: Calls my lord?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I pray you, sirs, lie in my tent and sleep;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: It may be I shall raise you by and by

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: On business to my brother Cassius.

speaker: VARRO
text_entry: So please you, we will stand and watch your pleasure.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I will not have it so: lie down, good sirs;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: It may be I shall otherwise bethink me.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Look, Lucius, here's the book I sought for so;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I put it in the pocket of my gown.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: VARRO and CLAUDIUS lie down

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: I was sure your lordship did not give it me.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Bear with me, good boy, I am much forgetful.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Canst thou hold up thy heavy eyes awhile,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And touch thy instrument a strain or two?

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Ay, my lord, an't please you.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: It does, my boy:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I trouble thee too much, but thou art willing.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: It is my duty, sir.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I should not urge thy duty past thy might;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I know young bloods look for a time of rest.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: I have slept, my lord, already.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: It was well done; and thou shalt sleep again;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I will not hold thee long: if I do live,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I will be good to thee.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Music, and a song

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: This is a sleepy tune. O murderous slumber,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Lay'st thou thy leaden mace upon my boy,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That plays thee music? Gentle knave, good night;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I will not do thee so much wrong to wake thee:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: If thou dost nod, thou break'st thy instrument;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I'll take it from thee; and, good boy, good night.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Let me see, let me see; is not the leaf turn'd down

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Where I left reading? Here it is, I think.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Enter the Ghost of CAESAR

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: How ill this taper burns! Ha! who comes here?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I think it is the weakness of mine eyes

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That shapes this monstrous apparition.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: It comes upon me. Art thou any thing?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Art thou some god, some angel, or some devil,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That makest my blood cold and my hair to stare?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Speak to me what thou art.

speaker: GHOST
text_entry: Thy evil spirit, Brutus.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Why comest thou?

speaker: GHOST
text_entry: To tell thee thou shalt see me at Philippi.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Well; then I shall see thee again?

speaker: GHOST
text_entry: Ay, at Philippi.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Why, I will see thee at Philippi, then.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Exit Ghost

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Now I have taken heart thou vanishest:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Ill spirit, I would hold more talk with thee.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Boy, Lucius! Varro! Claudius! Sirs, awake! Claudius!

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: The strings, my lord, are false.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: He thinks he still is at his instrument.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Lucius, awake!

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: My lord?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Didst thou dream, Lucius, that thou so criedst out?

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: My lord, I do not know that I did cry.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Yes, that thou didst: didst thou see any thing?

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Nothing, my lord.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Sleep again, Lucius. Sirrah Claudius!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: To VARRO

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Fellow thou, awake!

speaker: VARRO
text_entry: My lord?

speaker: CLAUDIUS
text_entry: My lord?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Why did you so cry out, sirs, in your sleep?

speaker: CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Did we, my lord?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Ay: saw you any thing?

speaker: VARRO
text_entry: No, my lord, I saw nothing.

speaker: CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Nor I, my lord.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Go and commend me to my brother Cassius;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Bid him set on his powers betimes before,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And we will follow.

speaker: CLAUDIUS
text_entry: It shall be done, my lord.

speaker: CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Exeunt
